title: Chapter 21
content:
Chapter 21

◎The Unattainable White Moonlight◎

Li Cheng enforced strict military discipline, and even during the training of the naval forces, he never drank alcohol. Being young and newly in charge of military affairs, he had to ensure that no one could criticize him.

However, his wife was an exception. Sometimes, he looked forward to festival gifts because it meant Huiyin would write him a letter and send some delicious food. Her letters weren’t long, but each word conveyed her deep concern. At the same time, she was very considerate. If there was nothing important, she would never write to him, fearing that she might disturb him.

Today, he only received a family letter, without any gifts. After Li Cheng opened the letter, he was stunned.

She was pregnant!

Li Cheng finally felt the reality of starting a family. Before, the idea of marriage was just about having a wife, and he wasn’t sure if she was truly devoted to him. He always felt he wasn’t ready, but now, unexpectedly, he was going to have a child connected to him by blood.

The letter mentioned that she suffered from severe morning sickness, but eating plum fruits had helped alleviate it. It also said that she might not be able to fully attend to Xun Rou…

After putting down the letter, Li Cheng thought of Xun Rou’s plea. She had begged him, saying that if she returned, the Grand Dowager would likely vent her anger on her. She mentioned how, although the Grand Dowager seemed kind to her, she was always testing her. He had refused to let her become a secondary consort, but it wasn’t right to send her away after just one month.

So, he agreed to let Xun Rou stay in the mansion. After all, the mansion was managed by Huiyin, so it should be fine. He hadn’t expected that now, with his wife pregnant, it really wasn’t appropriate to keep Xun Rou anymore.

These were secondary concerns. The most important thing was that he was going to be a father. His wife was quite beautiful, and he was quite handsome himself. Their child would surely be stunning!

Veteran followers like Yuwendang congratulated Li Cheng. The birth of an heir would solidify the position of the Prince of Huaiyin’s lineage.

Compared to Li Cheng’s joy, the Huaiyin Mansion was less enthusiastic. Some of the servants were old retainers, either people from Grand Dowager Wu or the former servants of Princess Cui. Granny Chao was unhappy. She crossed her legs and said to Yun Hui, “If the young princess gives birth to an heir, we won’t even have a place to stand.”

Currently, Nanny Nan, the mother of Princess Zheng, was helping manage the inner affairs of the second gate, directly liaising with Manager Zhong. The attendants she brought with her were gradually encroaching on the positions that these old servants had held.

Yun Hui advised, “Mother, don’t you think it’s good that the prince is nostalgic and hasn’t asked you to move out? He even lets me stay here as a manager. Isn’t that enough?”

At the end, she smiled slightly.

“With you being so indifferent to fame and fortune, I don’t know what to say,” Granny Chao said helplessly.

Yun Hui shook her head. “Then you should say nothing, and I’ll handle it.”

Granny Chao added, “That Miss Xun wanted to send you away before. Now, she’s practically under house arrest and can’t even leave the courtyard. It’s only fitting…”

Yun Hui smiled without responding.

Although Xun Rou was making a fuss about leaving, she was delicate and frail, so how could she possibly venture out on her own? Without the insignia of Huaiyin Mansion or a travel permit, she couldn’t even leave the mansion, let alone the city of Xuzhou.

However, that day, Huiyin, stroking her belly, smiled and said, “Send Miss Xun to Lady Miao’s residence. Today, the refuge for the displaced people is completed. She’s always capable. Oh, and send Yun Hui too. She’s very reliable.”

Xun Rou, annoyed to see Yun Hui sitting with her in the carriage, wished even more that Meixiang could deliver the message. However, Meixiang was in another carriage and couldn’t get off.

When they arrived at Lady Miao’s place, Yun Hui said, “Miss Xun, let me help you out of the carriage.”

Xun Rou still harbored a glimmer of hope that she could secretly pass a message when she went to the restroom. However, as soon as she stepped out of the carriage, the displaced people who had been kneeling there rushed towards her, holding sacks.

…

That morning, Huiyin had pigeon soup, which had been filtered several times to make it fresh and delicious. She asked Nanny Nan, “Did you send the letter to my mother? Has our person delivered it?”

“You can trust me. The letter has already been sent back,” Nanny Nan said with a smile.

Huiyin sighed with relief. “This is my first pregnancy, and the prince’s mother has passed away. There’s no one to consult about these matters of childbirth. If the pregnancy hadn’t stabilized by the third month, I wouldn’t have wanted to tell anyone.”

As the mistress and servant were talking, someone came in and said, “Young princess, something’s wrong. Miss Xun was taken away by the displaced people in a sack. Those were bandits from the woods, and it took a while before she was rescued. Incidentally, Yun Hui led the rescue and was injured in the process.”

Huiyin pretended to be furious. "I ordered you to follow her and take excellent care of her. How could this have happened? Someone, go get a doctor to attend to her. And make sure to send someone to check on Yun Hui as well."

In reality, when Xun Rou was returned, she had no physical injuries. However, in broad daylight, she had been abducted by male civilians and came back in disarray, her clothes disheveled. Everyone feared the worst had befallen her.

As she looked at Zheng Huiyin walking in, surrounded by servants, so radiant and majestic, Xun Rou glared, feeling as if she was blinded by Huiyin’s splendor.

Huiyin merely instructed those attending to Xun Rou, "You two must ensure Miss Xun is well cared for. If she is abducted again, I will hold you responsible."

Then she looked at Xun Rou and said, "The attendants who were supposed to protect you, including He Niangzi and Meixiang, failed in their duty. I have already punished them and sent them away. Rest assured, the Prince asked me to take care of you, and something like this will not happen again."

Xun Rou glared at her with venom, but Huiyin turned away without a second thought.

Late at night, when Xun Rou had no mood to sleep, she heard footsteps. To her surprise, it was Yun Hui. Yun Hui’s face still bore traces of a scrape. Xun Rou pointed at her and said, "Are you here to laugh at me?"

"Hahahaha," Yun Hui laughed.

The laughter echoed eerily in the quiet embroidery room.

"You, the noble Miss Xun, could have expelled me with just a hairpin, accusing me of having an affair. Now, you’ve become a joke in the entire Xuzhou city. Everyone says that you have been..." Yun Hui’s eyes flashed with resentment.

She had been by the Little Prince’s side for years, serving him since he was a child. He used to call her "Sister Yun Hui" all the time, as if she were family! She had watched him grow from a child to a handsome young man, and somewhere along the way, her heart had fallen for him. But she was falsely accused and expelled.

Her fiancé had also died, adding to her misfortune. She had been so kind to this new cousin, only to be framed by her. How could she accept this?

At that time, Xun Rou was so frail and unliked by the Grand Dowager Wu. It was Yun Hui who often told her what the Grand Dowager preferred, helping her gain favor.

Listening to Yun Hui, Xun Rou remembered a detail. When she told those men her identity, they let her go. But when Yun Hui "rescued" her, Xun Rou was pulling at her clothes, checking if anything was missing. In her panic, she hadn’t thought much of it, but now, she realized that the entire scene of being violated was staged by Yun Hui.

"It was you! You deliberately made others misunderstand me! I’m going to tell the Grand Dowager and my cousin!" Xun Rou stood up.

Yun Hui covered her mouth and laughed. "Go ahead and tell them. In everyone’s eyes, I’m the one who saved you, a great benefactor. As for you, you quarreled with the Prince, tried to frame the Princess, and now you have a tainted reputation. Xuzhou is not far from Jianye. When word of your reputation reaches the Grand Dowager Wu, how do you think she will view you?"

Xun Rou froze. She knew Yun Hui spoke the truth. The Grand Dowager liked her because she had been a constant companion, almost like a chief maid, managing the servants and taking care of tasks. But the Grand Dowager was also ruthless, as Xun Rou had witnessed.

Now, she had lost her influence. Li Cheng didn’t favor her, and Princess Zheng was smart enough to know what she had done. Even begging would be useless.

Seeing her like this, Yun Hui smiled and left. At the courtyard entrance, she stopped laughing and walked away with her back straight, just as she always had.

That night, Huiyin slept soundly. She used to suffer from insomnia, but ever since she was reborn and married Li Cheng, he had provided her with a sense of security, even if he didn’t love her. He always fulfilled her needs, and now she was pregnant so quickly.

Even if it isn’t an heir, they were still young, and it would happen eventually.

When she woke up in the morning, her favorite minced noodles were prepared in the kitchen. It was a pleasure for both body and mind. He Niangzi and He Guanshi had been sent away under a pretext, and now the kitchen was staffed by her own people, who knew what she liked to eat.

As she was enjoying her meal, someone reported outside, "Princess, Miss Xun is here."

Xun Rou wore a striking red dress, her dark hair contrasting sharply with the vibrant color, giving her an almost mad appearance.

"I’m here to say goodbye," she said to Huiyin.

Huiyin smiled. "You just had an incident yesterday, and now you want to leave? How will I explain this to the Prince?"

Xun Rou snorted. "Don’t worry, Cousin. I will write a letter to my cousin, saying that I miss my father and that I haven’t fulfilled my filial duties all these years."

"Very well, write it here. I can’t possibly stop you from fulfilling your filial duties. It would be best to write one to the Grand Dowager as well," Huiyin said.

Xun Rou sat down and wrote quickly. Huiyin reviewed both letters before saying, "I’ll arrange for someone to help you with the preparations."

Xun Rou sneered. "Cousin is truly thoughtful."

"As for who is truly thoughtful, we both know who that is," Huiyin said coldly.

Xun Rou didn’t dare to cause any trouble but looked at Huiyin and said, "Cousin, I admit defeat this time. I have nothing to say. We are both skilled in using schemes, our hearts not pure. But my cousin admires those who are innocent and kind. That person may not have high status or remarkable beauty, but he cherishes her innocence above all."

Huiyin laughed loudly. "He likes her so much, but he didn’t marry her. It’s not that impressive. You can’t provoke me. The strategies I use are not underhanded tricks but using the enemy’s own methods against them."

title: Chapter 22
content:
Chapter 22

◎How Different from the Previous Life◎

Since Xun Rou was heading to the capital, it wasn't as simple as just leaving; a team of guards had to be prepared to escort her. Huiyin, of course, wasn't keen on helping someone who had schemed against her, but since Xun Rou had already been taught a lesson, there was no need to kick her while she was down.

Yun Hui stood beside Huiyin, watching Xun Rou board the carriage. Knowing that Xun Rou's reputation was now in ruins, Yun Hui felt an indescribable sense of joy.

After Xun Rou left, Huiyin received a reply from Li Cheng. True to form, Li Cheng didn't disappoint her. He had arranged for Xun Rou to return to Jianye and asked about her well-being, saying he would come back to see her after some time.

"Why so wordy? He gave me a lot of instructions," Huiyin said, feeling a bit shy due to the detailed nature of Li Cheng's letter.

Nanny Nan said, "This is how the Little Prince shows his love for you."

Huiyin shook her head. She remembered what Xun Rou had told her—that Li Cheng had feelings for a girl who was pure and kind. But what did it matter? In a chaotic world, self-preservation was paramount. In the end, Li Cheng had married her. She wouldn't allow her husband to have any other woman in his heart.

After all, it was impossible for a woman to say she didn't care at all about who her husband loved. But caring wouldn't change anything. Moreover, it was quite possible that Xun Rou had made it all up. She couldn't afford to get angry at her husband over someone who might not even exist.

How to dispel such negative emotions? By reading books.

"Fugui, go buy some new books from the bookstore for me," Huiyin said with a smile.

After buying the books, she picked out the ones she liked and became immersed in them, forgetting to reply to Li Cheng's letter.

Li Cheng waited for ten days without receiving a reply from his wife. He asked the guard who had delivered the letter, "Did you hand-deliver it to my wife?"

"Yes, I handed it to Little Princess myself. She even gave me a generous reward. I waited for a few hours in the mansion, but since there was no reply, I left."

Li Cheng wondered if Huiyin was feeling unwell or upset. It was understandable; she was managing the household on her own while dealing with pregnancy.

Once the troops in Huai and Si completed their training, he planned to stay at Huaiyin Mansion in Xuzhou. Still, he couldn't afford to be too sentimental.

As the weather in Xuzhou started to turn cold, Huiyin found it hard to get out of bed in the morning. Winters in the south were entirely different from those in the north. In the north, they used heated brick beds (kang) which made sleeping warm and comfortable. In the south, the rooms were also very cold, requiring a charcoal brazier. With her pregnancy, she couldn't expose herself to the cold wind, so she stayed indoors, reading books.

By the Winter Solstice, her pregnancy was starting to show. The kitchen prepared tangyuan, glutinous rice balls filled with sweet fillings, which people in the south eat during the Winter Solstice. Huiyin adapted to the local customs and began to feel more at home.

"If I count the days, my mother should have received my letter by now," Huiyin said after finishing a tangyuan.

As soon as she finished speaking, she looked up and saw Li Cheng.

"Husband," Huiyin said, trying to get up to put on her clothes.

She was quite the morning sleeper, still in her nightgown, wrapped in a quilt, and eating in bed. She didn't expect Li Cheng to return at that moment, looking dusty from his journey.

Li Cheng saw her trying to get up and quickly came over to stop her. "Don't get up. You can't make such big movements when you're pregnant."

Li Cheng was delighted to see Huiyin's radiant smile. He took off his outer armor and changed into casual clothes. He picked up the leftover tangyuan and ate them, then placed his hand on Huiyin's belly. "You've worked hard. I'm not by your side."

"It's okay. Although I have to manage the household, it's much quieter now. By the way, your cousin Xun Rou has gone to the capital, saying she wants to pay filial respects there. I sent her letter to your grandmother. Since I received your letter saying you had already sent her away, I didn’t forward her message. Here it is for you."

Li Cheng waved his hand. "It's good that she's gone. Forget about her. How about you? How are you?"

"At first, I felt nauseous and couldn't eat. After three months, it got much better. Now, when I place my hand on my belly, the baby even greets me," Huiyin said with a smile.

Li Cheng immediately wanted to try. He naturally placed his hand on Huiyin's belly, and Huiyin felt a slight tingle. She gently placed her hand over his, feeling the warmth of his touch.

Li Cheng seemed to feel something too and looked up to see Huiyin gazing at him.

"Is something on your mind?"

"Did you come back just for me?" Huiyin asked.

Li Cheng had originally planned to return for the New Year, but as the Winter Solstice approached, he felt a twinge of compassion for Zheng Shi, who was alone and pregnant, and decided to come back early.

He didn’t know how to respond to his wife’s eager gaze. She seemed to love him too much, her emotions completely revolving around him. But he couldn’t bring himself to respond to such intense affection right now, so he lowered his head and simply said, "Mm."

**

Madame Ji had already received the letter and was preparing a variety of tonics to send to Xuzhou. Xin Shi, who had experience from raising her own son, sent over her son’s old pillow, some clothes he had worn, and even made a patchwork garment to add to the package.

"Madam, our younger sister has certainly done well for herself. She became pregnant shortly after her marriage. It seems the Prince of Huaiyin really dotes on her. Now you can finally rest easy," Xin Shi said with a smile.

Madame Ji was also very pleased. "I originally planned to have Shuo'er deliver the items and take the opportunity to get to know his brother-in-law. But the Marquis assigned Shuo'er to meet with Wei Duo. So I had no choice but to send Heng'er instead. As you know, Heng'er has never traveled far before, and I’m quite worried about it."

After listening to Madame Ji, Xin Shi secretly thought that she was being partial. This was a rare opportunity to meet the Prince of Huaiyin, yet she only sent her younger son.

But Xin Shi kept her thoughts to herself. Instead, she went back and prepared more gifts. Her husband had a close relationship with Princess Zheng, and this time Huiyin had even written a letter to her husband specifically.

While Madame Ji and others were thinking about the return gift, Elder Madame Xu was surprised and worried. She hadn’t expected Huiyin, who had married out a few months later, to get pregnant so quickly.

Zheng Deyin was equally shocked and exclaimed, "That’s impossible!"

Elder Madame Xu said, "She’s already been pregnant for three months. I heard that the Little Prince really dotes on her. After going to Xuzhou, he stayed there with her and even rushed back to accompany her during the Mid-Autumn Festival. She’s truly blessed."

Zheng Deyin hadn’t expected her younger sister to end up in such a situation after marrying. She remembered that in her previous life, she had spent the Mid-Autumn Festival with Grand Dowager Wu. Li Cheng only returned once a year, and she couldn’t conceive. A year later, Grand Dowager Wu arranged for Xun Rou to marry Li Cheng as a secondary consort. Xun Rou was very respectful to her. She thought that instead of having someone unfamiliar, a concubine granted by Prince Wei, it was better to have Xun Rou. At least Xun Rou would be easier to manage.

Who would have thought that Li Cheng would dote on the daughter of a low-ranking official rather than favor Xun Rou?

title: Chapter 23
content:
Chapter 23

◎Game of Wits◎

As the first light of dawn broke, Huiyin opened her eyes and realized she was nestled in Li Cheng's arms, her whole body slick with sweat. He felt like a furnace, and though Huiyin wanted to kiss him, she held back, remembering she hadn't freshened up yet.

Li Cheng, having been in the military for many years, was a light sleeper. He sensed Huiyin had woken up and immediately looked at her.

At that moment, Huiyin's raven-black hair cascaded smoothly over her shoulders. Her skin was fair and soft, like tofu, but dark circles under her eyes marred her complexion from sleeping late. Yet, this did not diminish her beauty; instead, it gave her a certain alluring, disheveled charm.

"I told you to read less last night, but you wouldn't listen. You even asked me to play the qin (a traditional Chinese stringed instrument) to entertain you. Look at those dark circles. You're so naughty," Li Cheng said, gently scraping her nose.

Huiyin rubbed her belly and replied, "I still feel like a child myself, even though I've just gotten married. But now I'm a mother. To be honest, every morning when I wake up, I'm reminded that I'm carrying a child. I can't move much, can't catch a breeze, and I can't even wash my hair or bathe freely. I know all women go through this during pregnancy, but I just feel uncomfortable. It's frustrating."

Hearing this, Li Cheng became unexpectedly eloquent. "How could you be the same as other women? You've always been pampered and are my wife, Li Cheng's wife. How could you be compared to others? I do keep you in my heart."

"Yunzhi (Li Cheng's courtesy name), even though you don't say it, I know you came back mostly for me," Huiyin said quietly.

Li Cheng kissed her hand. "Yes, I do miss you."

With that thought, he quickly got up. "I'll have someone bring breakfast over. We'll eat together."

"No, I should get up. Let's have our meal in the small hall. We can have the brazier (a portable heater) set up first," Huiyin said as she prepared to rise.

Li Cheng looked outside. "It's too windy and snowy. Let's eat on the daybed. I'll carry you to the daybed and set up the table. We'll eat together."

Huiyin blushed. "No, no. If you weren't here, I might be lazy, but now that you're back, people will talk if I act this way."

Even at home, although her mother doted on her, her upbringing was strict, and such indulgence wasn't allowed.

But Li Cheng said, "Why get up? It's too cold. If I don't say anything, who dares to say anything about you? Just stay here. I'll carry you to the daybed."

He was very strong and easily lifted Huiyin, who wasn't particularly light. Nestled on the daybed, Huiyin felt both familiar and strange with him. He doted on her, though he rarely admitted it. He was straightforward in his speech and sometimes liked to debate, but he never argued with her.

She had breakfast on the daybed—lamb broth with noodles. After finishing the bowl, she felt like she would gain several pounds (jin is a Chinese weight measure).

Normally, she didn't deliberately eat less, but she only ate a small portion. After the first three months of pregnancy, her appetite had improved, but if the baby was over-nourished, it could lead to a difficult birth. Giving birth was important, but her own life mattered more.

Seeing her finish, Li Cheng seemed a bit troubled and asked, "What's wrong? Was the food not to your liking? You told me yesterday that walnuts (considered nutritious for pregnant women) were good for you."

He rarely showed concern for others because if you cared too much, people might think you were too invested and start acting superior.

"I ate too much this morning. I need to get up and move around a bit. Also, I have something to discuss with you. I forgot to mention it yesterday," Huiyin said, then rang the bell to call someone in to help her dress.

She then mentioned that she had already written to her family about her pregnancy. "My mother loves me dearly. I wonder if she'll send something over. Also, if my brother or younger brother comes, should I inform you?"

Li Cheng immediately replied, "If your brothers come, send me a letter, and I'll take them to meet the Prince of Wei."

"That's great. But they might not come. By saying this, I know how to handle it," Huiyin said.

Li Cheng thought to himself that she really did keep him in her heart. She even discussed her brothers visiting with him, listening to his opinion on everything. This made him very happy.

"We should keep them for an extended stay," he said.

"Yes," Huiyin replied, equally pleased.

At this stage, they were still being polite to each other, but Li Cheng's personality was starting to show. For example, during lunch, Huiyin casually mentioned a murder case in Xuzhou. It turned out that the only daughter of the local wealthy Xiao family had married the judicial officer of the prefecture, who came from a poor family. Their relationship was strained, and one day he slapped her. She then wanted to marry one of the judicial officer's friends, leading to their divorce. The divorce was finalized, and the young lady remarried. However, her new husband died, and his family accused her of causing his death.

According to Huiyin's guess, it definitely wouldn't be Madame Xiao who committed the crime: "As far as I know, Madame Xiao and her new husband, Wang Maocai, were deeply in love and only got together after much difficulty with their divorce. How could she have killed her new husband? I'm certain that the Wang family, who never approved of their son marrying a woman who had been married before, is now blaming the woman after their son died."

However, Li Cheng said, "That pair of contemptible people got what was coming to them."

"How can you say that? Although a woman is expected to remain faithful to one husband, if a couple has no affection for each other and the husband even beats his wife, divorce is not out of the question. I even heard that this military magistrate embezzled funds and made the Xiao family pay for it. As for Wang Maocai and his wife, they weren't really on the same path either; it's said that all his assets were given to his first wife before he married Madame Xiao, which shows that their love was quite strong." When Huiyin was young and studied "Nü De" (Women's Virtue) and "Nü Jie" (Women's Admonitions), she always felt that her teacher was subtly criticizing her mother, Madame Ji, which made her feel ashamed. Even hearing the term 'fickle' made her fear it might implicate her mother.

But as she grew older, she realized how difficult life was for women. Marriages were blind, arranged by parents, and perhaps the person you married wasn't suitable at all. So why couldn't you choose someone else?

As she said this, seeing Li Cheng's face turn ashen, she wisely fell silent.

Li Cheng, however, was deeply shocked. He found that although Princess Zheng rarely left the mansion according to the servants, she was not easy to control and seemed different from other women. She didn't agree with the idea of being faithful to one husband and even scoffed at the traditional virtues of women.

Men liked a bit of a challenge. If you were too gentle and obedient, it wasn't as exciting. She wouldn't unconditionally obey just because you were her husband.

After this conversation, the atmosphere between them became somewhat tense, despite previously getting along well.

Nanny Nan quietly said to Huiyin, "Young princess, why talk about this? It's hard enough for the Little Prince to come back home; no man likes to hear his wife mention divorce."

"Mother, you don't understand. Men like a bit of a challenge. If you're too gentle and virtuous, it's not appealing. Don't worry, even though he's upset with me now, he'll eventually start to worry about me." Huiyin said with a slow smile.

Nanny Nan nodded inwardly but still felt a little worried.

Huiyin, however, had no such concerns. Because Li Cheng loved to get to the bottom of things and had strong execution, such a person was highly competitive.

The couple used to often dine together, but tonight Li Cheng said he had matters outside and wouldn't be coming back. Since Huiyin had eaten a lot in the morning and had chestnuts and snacks in the afternoon, she was quite happy to eat less in the evening when he wasn't around.

Nanny Nan, who was devoted to Huiyin, couldn't help but say, "Maybe you should skip the snacks tomorrow. If you eat too many, you won't want to eat your meals."

"I know, I just can't control my cravings. But I need to control myself, even if it's hard." Huiyin said with a smile.

In the evening, she ate a small bowl of rice, a plate of vegetables, and a plate of lean meat, giving the rest of the dishes to the servants and maids. She also walked around the small hall ten times to help digestion, which made her feel much more comfortable.

Li Cheng deliberately came back late; he was upset but couldn't express it or say anything harsh to his wife. From his perspective, he naturally hoped his wife would be of one mind with him and remain utterly loyal. However, although she treated him well on the surface, unintentional remarks revealed her true thoughts.

If she found her husband lacking, it was natural for her to leave, and she could even abandon her husband for someone she liked.

With Huiyin's beauty and capabilities, she was a rare woman in the world, decisive and unconstrained in her actions. If such a woman were to remarry, she would likely thrive, just like her mother, Madame Zheng. Back then, Madame Zheng was the wife of Pei Ye, the Duke of Gaoping Commandery. When Pei Ye took a concubine, Madame Zheng decisively chose to divorce him and later married Zheng Fang.

With a mother like hers, it was no surprise that Huiyin was different from other women.

He must make Princess Zheng truly love and depend on him so much that she couldn't live without him. With this thought in mind, he lifted the curtain and entered.

Huiyin was an avid reader; she loved books as much as life itself. Hearing footsteps, she looked up and immediately stood up when she saw Li Cheng enter, saying, "Have you eaten? I heard you had matters outside this evening, so I ate first."

Li Cheng sat down and said, with apparent "understanding," "Don't worry about me. Right now, the baby in your belly and you are far more important than I am."

"Why would you say that? You're very important to me too. I've always been concerned about you. I was worried you hadn't eaten well, so I had the kitchen prepare some food for you." Huiyin said with a smile.

Li Cheng had been thinking a lot about how to gain her obedience and loyalty, but this simple concern made him instantly happy: "You've been thinking of me? Actually, I haven't eaten yet, I didn't want to trouble you."

Huiyin found it strange; it wasn't as if she was doing the cooking herself. It was just a matter of instructing the kitchen staff, so what trouble was there?

title: Chapter 24
content:
Chapter 24

◎Lady Xie◎

After the Winter Solstice, Li Cheng stayed for only one more day before he had to depart for Huai and Si to train the troops. Before leaving, he instructed Huiyin, “The other families in Xuzhou are fine, but the Grand Dowager of the Xue family is an exception. She was a daughter of the imperial clan, the daughter of the Prince of Xin, and honored as the County Lady of Linchuan. I received an invitation from the Xue family yesterday, so please go on my behalf and bring a generous gift.”

“Yes, I will. You take care as well, it's cold and the northern wind is fierce,” Huiyin replied, also reluctant to see him go.

Li Cheng gently touched her face, “You don’t need to wake up early every day, just rest well.”

Though he came and went quickly, it was reassuring that he still made time to see her.

Speaking of the Xue family, Huiyin had met them once before at their mansion. They were extremely respectful toward her. This time, when Li Cheng returned, they visited again, showing an excessive level of respect, likely trying to curry favor with him.

However, before the Grand Dowager Xue’s birthday, Xuzhou city had already started to buzz with excitement. Huaiyin Mansion also welcomed new guests—the wife of Xie Jiuyi, the Prefect of Huaihai, came to visit.

Chief Steward Guo Qishan introduced, “The Xie family, originally from Chen County, has been established here for many years. It was with their help that the Prince of Wei was able to successfully establish himself in the Jiangnan region. Lady Xie is also the younger sister of Lady Yin, the consort of the Prince of Wei.”

Huiyin had previously reviewed the gift records and noted that the most generous gifts to Huaiyin Mansion over the years came from the Xie family and the Prince of Wei’s Mansion. Although Lady Yin was not the principal consort, she held a high position for giving birth to the Prince of Wei’s eldest son.

As Huiyin was thinking about how to make small talk with Lady Xie, she didn’t notice the hesitant expression of Chief Steward Guo.

Since the master of Huaiyin Mansion was not present, Huiyin had the chief steward entertain the male guests while she personally received the female guests. Nanny Nan also advised, “Lady Xie is not only the prefect’s wife but also the full sister of Lady Yin, the consort of the Prince of Wei. We must not neglect her.”

“That’s exactly what I thought. It’s just that the Little Prince is not in the mansion, and I’m not very familiar with these relationships, so I’m really afraid of offending someone,” Huiyin said, feeling helpless.

The challenge was that, without her husband around, she couldn’t consult him on important matters.

Huiyin hadn’t been back to Jianye yet, and she had already met fewer people. Once she returned to Jianye, there would be the Grand Dowager Wu of the Prince of Wei, the Princess of the Wei family, and many other imperial relatives and officials—truly a multitude.

Some people harbored grudges against the Zheng family, so Huiyin felt pressured to conceive quickly. She knew that next year would be turbulent, and having a child would strengthen her position.

Thinking of this, she instructed Dong Shun, “The fresh fruits stored in the ice cellar can be brought out—green plums, hard pears, cherries, ganzi, and grapes must be served. Also, prepare a platter with lychees, pomelos, loquats, and purple pears.”

The purple pears were precious and hard to come by, not to mention the lychees. Some of these fruits, Huiyin herself couldn’t bear to eat.

Fresh fruits in winter are especially precious, and rare delicacies like ice-preserved sturgeon and abalone should be used to honor our guests.

Fugui asked, “What kind of tea should we serve? We’ve just received premium dried fruits, melon seeds, and other fine dried goods in the mansion, which are excellent for brewing tea.”

“No, just use plain tea. Mixed tea is a commoner’s way of drinking tea. I personally enjoy it, but we can’t be so casual when we have guests,” Huiyin replied.

Upon hearing this, Fugui complied. These maids used to only need to serve their mistress when they were in the Marquis of Zhaojie’s residence. Now, in the prince’s mansion, they also had to help the young lady manage the household. Each of the four senior maids had specific duties, and their future roles would depend on how well they performed before marriage.

Fugui, in particular, had ambitions. She wanted to become the head stewardess, so she had to ensure everything was handled perfectly.

Huiyin felt as if she were preparing for a crucial battle. It wasn’t that she feared them, but she was concerned about inadvertently offending someone. After all, Li Cheng was still relying on the support of the Prince of Wei. She couldn’t afford to overlook anyone.

Soon, she met Lady Xie, who was completely different from what she had imagined. Lady Xie was about the same age as her, with a striking appearance—graceful and elegant, her hair styled high and adorned with elaborate hairpins, giving off an aura of humility while making others feel at ease.

“Your Highness,” Lady Xie greeted respectfully.

“Lady Xie, no need for such formality,” Huiyin replied with a smile.

Lady Xie was momentarily taken aback. She had only heard that Li Cheng had married but didn’t know that his wife was so beautiful. The only word she could think of to describe her was “peerless beauty,” like Daji—a phrase used to depict an enchanting and seductive appearance.

Her beauty was so striking that it could leave others speechless, yet Lady Zheng remained humble. Instead, she complimented Lady Xie, “I see that Lady Xie has an elegant demeanor and graceful movements, with a celestial appearance. It’s truly an honor to have you in our humble abode.”

“Your Highness is too kind. I’ve often heard that the beauties of Yan and Zhao are unparalleled, with jade-like beauty. Now that I’ve met Your Highness, I know this to be true,” Lady Xie complimented in return.

Huiyin waved her hand. "Please, no need for formalities. Please, come with me to the small hall for a conversation."

They were not very familiar with each other, but Lady Xie was quite candid. "I am extremely close friends with the granddaughter of the Grand Lady Xue. Her grandmother had helped me a great deal in the past, and the Xue family has been a family friend of my husband's for generations, which is why we rushed over from Luanzhou."

"I see. My prince returned just a few days ago during the Winter Solstice and instructed me to attend the Grand Lady Xue's birthday celebration. However, I don't know them well. Now that you're here, I have someone to talk to. Why don't you and your family stay at our mansion for a while?" Huiyin said with a smile.

As they exchanged pleasantries, the maids filed in. Lady Xie glanced lightly around and saw the rare fruits and luxurious snacks, nodding to herself in approval. It was reassuring to see that there was a capable mistress managing the mansion. It seemed Li Cheng had moved on from his past and settled into his role, which was good for everyone.

Seeing that Lady Xie was straightforward, Huiyin began to probe for information. "When did you and Lord Xie first meet my husband? I first married into this family, and the Prince was always away training troops. I'm always afraid that I might unknowingly offend someone due to my ignorance of these relationships."

Lady Xie shared quite a bit, mostly about how her maternal family, the Yin family, was in the fiefdom of the Prince of Wu, and that they had grown up together.

"When we were very young, we both studied under a famous scholar in Wu. Your prince was about three years older than me, and I was just three at the time. Cheng Brother was so picky. We all ate the scholar's meals, but he refused. We all took afternoon naps together, but he wouldn't sleep. He was always criticizing us. The first day he saw the characters I wrote, he told the scholar to expel me, saying that a person like me was a crow and could never become a phoenix. But I didn't give up. Can you imagine how harsh he could be? But now, I've heard that the two of you are a loving couple, and I suppose he has changed a lot because of you. You two must have a deep bond." Lady Xie genuinely hoped that her senior prince would be happy.

However, her words weighed heavily on Huiyin's heart. Could it be that Lady Xie was the one Li Cheng truly loved?

If that was the case, then Lady Xie was like a more refined version of Lu Xiao. She was warm, kind, and capable—someone more difficult to deal with than a villain. Someone like Xun Rou, who often made mistakes, was easier to handle. But how does one handle a genuinely good-hearted person?

title: Chapter 25
content:
Chapter 25

Siblings Reunion (Including VIP Notice)

Lord Xie and Lady Xie had separate accommodations, so they bid farewell to Huiyin. Huiyin also took the opportunity to meet this young Haihai Prefect. He was probably a couple of years older than Li Cheng and was a handsome man, appearing more mature. Li Cheng’s eyes always sparkled, unconsciously revealing a natural youthful aura. Lord Xie was much more composed.

"Manager Qiao, it's difficult to buy charcoal in Xuzhou during winter. Please send some to Lord Xie and his wife on my behalf," Huiyin said.

Manager Qiao quickly smiled and replied, "Yes, I will arrange it right away."

It was evident that Manager Qiao was also quite familiar with Lord Xie and his wife, as he behaved more casually with them.

Huiyin couldn't help but say, "Wait, Manager Qiao, I want to ask you something."

Manager Qiao stood with his hands by his sides, waiting for Huiyin’s question, but after a moment of thought, she said, "Never mind, go ahead and see if they need anything else."

Manager Qiao, although puzzled, left first.

Huiyin stroked her belly and wandered the corridor, lost in thought. Begging for love, or winning it through submission, was not true love. She absolutely did not acknowledge it.

She had been slightly influenced by Xun Rou’s words, but she couldn’t let them make her suspicious of everyone. She must always believe in herself, Huiyin secretly resolved.

After calming her mind for half a day, by the time of Lady Xue’s birthday banquet three days later, she was able to chat and laugh naturally. Lady Xue’s granddaughter was married to a former subordinate of Lord Xie, who now held the position of Tunqi Colonel.

Xue Huanhuan, the pet name of Lady Xue, was held by Elder Lady Xue as she said to Lady Xie, "Liyi, Huanhuan has always been close to you, and I am relieved. I am old and may not be able to look after her for much longer."

Lady Xie’s maiden name was Yin, and her given name was Liyi. She was the daughter of a recorder under the Prince of Wei, later marrying Xie Miu. However, Huiyin found it strange that the recorder was only a low-ranking official of the seventh or eighth rank, and the Yin family was not a prominent clan. How did she manage to marry the son of a prefect?

As she pondered, she heard Yin Liyi say, "Why would you say that, Elder Lady Xue? I was fortunate to have Lady Xue’s care, and she was my best friend. Before I came, my mother specially asked me to bring some of her favorite hazelnut cakes."

Upon hearing this, Xue Huanhuan was quite moved and even wiped away some tears. "It's already been more than five years. I still remember when I was a lady-in-waiting by the side of the Wei Imperial Consort, and Liyi was only twelve or thirteen years old. I had never met a girl who was both so innocent and yet so driven. She was the hardest-working person I’ve ever known."

Huiyin thought to herself that Yin Liyi had been a lady-in-waiting in the Prince of Wei’s mansion, and exactly five years ago, Li Cheng’s parents had passed away, and he had come to rely on the Prince of Wei, certainly living in his mansion as well. Childhood friends reuniting after a long separation, who knows what had happened?

Just as she was thinking this, Elder Lady Xue, noticing that Xue Huanhuan was talking non-stop and afraid of neglecting Huiyin, quickly added, "You may not know this, Young Princess, but my granddaughter was a lady-in-waiting for the Wei Imperial Consort. I wanted her to learn proper etiquette. Back then, I often spoke with your great-grandmother as well. Young Prince Xie was not yet of age but was extremely skilled in martial arts. Whenever he led the Prince of Wei’s vanguard, his bravery and skill were unmatched."

Huiyin, appearing interested, smiled and said, "In Jizhou, I often heard of the Prince of Huaiyin’s bravery."

Lady Miao, who had previously caused some damage to Xun Rou’s reputation due to the resettlement of refugees, noticed that the Young Princess did not blame her and still valued her. She quickly chimed in, "Young Princess, it is said that your father was known as the Flying General and has now been enfeoffed as the Marquis of Zhaojie and the Grand Commander of Jizhou. Your younger brother will soon arrive in our Xuzhou. I wonder what kind of demeanor he will have? I’m sure the young ladies of Xuzhou are eager to see him."

Huiyin smiled and replied, "My younger brother is still young. We originally thought my older brother would come, but we received a letter saying he will be the one coming instead. When he arrives, I will host a banquet for everyone."

Lady Miao quickly caught on, as did Lady Xue from the Xue family. Li Cheng now oversaw Xuzhou. They were treating Yin Liyi with great respect due to Lord Xie and the Prince of Wei, but they had forgotten that the local official is more relevant than a distant superior. Moreover, the father of Princess Zheng was the Marquis of Zhaoping, not from a prominent family but trusted by Prime Minister Lü Wei.

Huiyin did not wish to be the center of attention and quickly returned the focus to Elder Lady Xue. "Our young prince specifically asked me to come and wish you a long life, as he said you were very close with his grandmother. Besides the birthday gifts, I have also personally copied the 'Heart Sutra of Prajna Paramita' to present to you."

"Thank you, Young Princess," said Elder Lady Xue, as she had someone receive it. Upon flipping through a few pages, she saw the elegant and flowing calligraphy and couldn't help but nod in approval.

She then said, "I am pregnant, so it is inconvenient for me to stay for the meal. Perhaps another time, I will invite everyone over."

Elder Lady Xue wanted to see her off, but Huiyin stopped her.

After she left, Elder Lady Xue said to those around her, "This Young Princess does not put on airs and possesses both beauty and grace. She is truly remarkable."

Yin Liyi, having interacted with many people as a lady-in-waiting in the Prince of Wei’s mansion, had seen many people, but she could not quite figure out Princess Zheng. Xue Huanhuan thought the same. She said, "My mother told me that this Princess Zheng usually keeps to herself, but in just a few months, the Huaiyin Mansion is almost entirely under her command. Entering the mansion already pregnant and yet able to hold herself back. It is said that Xun Rou was..."

The last few words were spoken almost imperceptibly.

Yin Liyi was startled. "Her methods are indeed ruthless."

"That's right. Speaking of which, we have no connection to the Little Prince nowadays. Just think about the Prince of Huaiyin—known for his sharp tongue and ruthless nature. Yet, he actually rushes back during the Mid-Autumn Festival and Winter Solstice just to spend the holidays with her." When Xue Huanhuan was a lady-in-waiting at the Prince of Wei’s mansion, the Prince of Wei, fearing that the Prince of Huaiyin wouldn’t be able to manage his own estate, had him help manage the Wei Mansion instead. Xue Huanhuan had worked under Li Cheng, and while she admitted that Li Cheng was very capable, working under him was incredibly stressful.

Both Yin Liyi and her sister were daughters of officials in the Wei Mansion and had been acquaintances of Li Cheng. He hadn’t shown them much mercy either.

It was only toward this woman from the Zheng family that he seemed to be an exception. Thinking of this, Yin Liyi glanced at Xue Huanhuan again and said, "Never mind, I won’t mention others. Let me ask you, are you and your husband preparing to head north?"

It should be known that Xie Jiuyi is not only a prefect but also one of the foremost loyal officials under the Prince of Wei. There is a children's song in the Jiangnan region that goes: "Xie Jiuyi guards the roads, while Li Cheng commands the waters."

This refers to Xie Jiuyi and Li Cheng. The Jiangnan region has always been rich in talented individuals. Moreover, Xie Jiuyi is quite close to the Prince of Wei and can be considered a strategist. Heading north must be for something important, Xue Huanhuan speculated privately.

Yin Liyi smiled and said, "Your information is quite accurate, but before that, we still need to meet with the Prince of Huaiyin to discuss matters."

Xue Huanhuan, understanding the boundaries, didn’t ask further, as she knew clearly that the Prince of Wei wanted to take Qingzhou as soon as possible and that the marriage alliance with Zheng Fang of Jizhou was intended to keep Zheng Fang neutral.

More than a month after Elder Madame Xu’s birthday celebration, Huiyin’s pregnancy was showing more. Every day, besides managing the household and reviewing accounts, she spent her days resting at home. Anyway, Li Cheng had said he would return by the New Year, which was only a few days away. The house was already adorned with lanterns and colorful decorations, filled with a festive atmosphere.

However, before Li Cheng returned, Huiyin’s younger brother, Zheng Wuheng, arrived.

He came from Jizhou, accompanied by his father’s advisor, Counselor Zhuang Huai, and brought several fine horses and a dozen carts of gifts intended for the Prince of Huaiyin and the Prince of Wei.

The young man, on his first trip away from home, had been trying to appear composed and serious along the way, but upon seeing his elder sister, he ran over with a smile, just like always. "Sister."

"Heng'er," Huiyin, who had spent half a year in Xuzhou, often felt lonely being alone in the mansion. After becoming pregnant, her emotions had become more sentimental. Now, seeing a family member, her joy was evident.

Zheng Wuheng noticed that his sister looked much healthier and more radiant after marrying into the family. Her clothes were elegant and luxurious, and she appeared much more at ease. There was none of that haggard look of someone who had been far from home and family, which put his mind slightly at ease.

"Sister, where is Brother-in-law? Is he good to you?" This was the question Zheng Wuheng was most concerned about.

Huiyin, not wanting to worry her younger brother, put things in a positive light: "Your brother-in-law treats me well. Although we don’t spend much time together, he always rushes back during festivals to accompany me. He’ll be back in a few days, and then you two can meet."

Zheng Wuheng let out a sigh of relief. "If Brother-in-law treats you well, I’m relieved. By the way, this time, I brought letters from our parents."

The siblings entered the inner room, and Huiyin quickly scanned the letter. Madame Ji, of course, first expressed concern about her health and then mentioned that recently De Yin seemed to be persuading Elder Madame Xu to advise their father to turn against Lü Wei. As for their father, he was asking about the situation in Xuzhou, about Li Cheng, and about the Prince of Wei.

Huiyin looked at Zheng Wuheng and said, "My dear brother, remember this: no matter who tries to convince our father to oppose Lü Wei, he must stay calm and not act rashly."

Zheng Wuheng was puzzled. "Sister, Lü Wei holds the emperor under his control and shows much disrespect toward the Crown Prince. The people have long suffered under his tyranny. If our father were to rise, wouldn’t he become the leader?"

"You’re mistaken. Back when the incident with Lu Ji occurred, after our father killed Lu Ji, he had to flee. Who came to his aid then? If Lü Wei dies, our father will lose soldiers and resources, and others will likely reap the benefits. Our Zheng family has risen from humble beginnings and has only recently established a foothold in Jizhou. We cannot afford to make any missteps now. Even when it comes to what your brother-in-law says, our father doesn’t have to follow it blindly." Huiyin advised.

Zheng Wuheng, who had always followed his sister’s words, saw her write a reply letter and solemnly agreed.

However, Huiyin was thinking about her previous life in the Eastern Palace. If she hadn’t discovered the matter of the contraceptive medicine and quietly became pregnant, she wouldn’t have persuaded her father to turn against Lü Wei. She poisoned Li Heng and seized power. But her brother took Li Heng’s place and died from a poisoned arrow, which was a pain she could hardly bear.

At that time, she had truly believed that Li Heng genuinely loved her and that she would one day become empress legitimately, which was why she had asked her family to support her wholeheartedly. But things ended up differently, so how could she trust Li Cheng now?

Moreover, there was Yin Liyi, who seemed to be Li Cheng’s 'first love' lingering in Xuzhou, seemingly waiting for him to return, often sending messengers to check on him. Although Huiyin knew that Yin Liyi and her husband seemed very happy and affectionate now, she always felt that this woman knew Li Cheng too well…

It was a feeling that even Xun Rou, who had grown up alongside her cousin Li Cheng, didn’t give her.

Just as she was thinking this, Manager Qiao said, "Young Princess, the Little Prince has sent his soldiers and servants ahead."

Huiyin was startled.
